qas.question: In a computational problem, what can be described as a string over an alphabet?
What is the name of the alphabet is most commonly used in a problem instance?
What is another term for the string of a problem instance?
In the encoding of mathematical objects, what is the way in which integers are commonly expressed?
What is one way in which graphs can be encoded?
What is a string over a Greek number when considering a computational problem?
What is the name of the alphabet that is rarely used in a problem instance?
What is another term for the the string of a problem question?
What is represented by non-binary notation in the encoding of mathematical objects?

plausible_answers.text: via their adjacency matrices, or by encoding their adjacency lists in binary.

qas.question: How can graphs be encoded indirectly?

context: When considering computational problems, <a0_1>a <a0_0><a0_2><b5_0>problem instance<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> is a string over an alphabet. Usually, the alphabet is taken to be the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>binary<a1_2/><a1_1/> alphabet<b6_0/><a1_0/> (i.e., the set {0,1}), and thus the strings are <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>bitstrings<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. As in a real-world computer, mathematical objects other than bitstrings must be suitably encoded. For example, <b8_0>integers<b8_0/> can be represented in <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>binary notation<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, and graphs can be encoded <a4_1>directly <b9_0>via their <a4_0>adjacency matrices<a4_1/><a4_0/>, or by encoding their adjacency lists in binary.
